dublin_core.dcvalue: We investigated whether allied health assessments carried out via videoconferencing were comparable to assessments carried out face to face Five allied health therapists in dietetics occupational therapy physiotherapy podiatry and speech pathology conducted an assessment of 12 high dependency residents both face to face and by videoconferencing On a five point Likert scale the therapists mean ratings for the efficiency and suitability of videoconferencing for assessment were significantly lower than for face to face Their mean rating for the adequacy of their care plans was also significantly lower for videoconferencing than for face to face However in each case the dietician s assessments did not differ significantly between the two modalities In 35 cases out of 60 two independent raters agreed that the therapists care plans after the videoconferencing and face to face assessments were the same However the level of agreement between raters was only moderate kappa 0 31 Despite the therapists natural preference for face to face working care plans formulated via videoconferencing were reasonably similar to those formulated in face to face assessment Allied health assessments carried out by videoconferencing would therefore seem to be feasible
Preliminary experience of allied health assessments delivered face to face and by videoconference to a residential facility for elderly people.
